prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for telling their friend that her being single is due to having five kids with different fathers. 

First, I need to break down the situation. The friend has been making insulting comments about the author's weight, job, dating life, etc., for two years. The author tried to brush it off with polite responses each time. Finally, when the friend asked again, the author gave a direct answer pointing out the friend's situation as a reason she's still single. The friend got angry and hung up. Now mutual friends are calling the author out for being privileged and a bad friend, even though the author feels they're not privileged and that the friend's comments were hurtful.

The key points here are about the context of the insults and the friend's behavior over time. The author was defending themselves after repeated attacks, which might justify their response. However, the way the author phrased it could be seen as harsh or judgmental. The friend's actions might be part of her own issues, but the author's response might have crossed a line by pointing out the friend's situation in a way that could be perceived as shaming.

But considering that the author had been insulted multiple times and finally stood up for themselves, some might argue that the response was a legitimate defense. However, the content of the response—mentioning the friend's five kids with different fathers—could be hurtful and stigmatizing. Even if it's true, it's a sensitive issue, and bringing it up might not be the best approach, even in the face of insults.

Also, the mutual friends' reactions suggest that the author's statement was hurtful in a way that wasn't appreciated, possibly due to the friend's personal circumstances. The author's job in the adult industry might add to the perception of privilege, even if it's not the case. The author's response could be seen as invalidating the friend's struggles, even if the friend is acting out.

On the other hand, the author was defending themselves against untrue and low-quality insults, which might make their response more understandable. The question is whether the response was proportionate. The friend's behavior was definitely problematic, but the author's truth-telling might have been an appropriate reaction in a healthy friendship. However, in this case, the friend's behavior was hostile, and the author's response might not have been the best way to handle it.

So, considering all factors, the author's response might be seen as crossing a line even if the friend was being difficult. The better approach might have been to set boundaries without attacking the friend's personal situation. Therefore, the answer would be A (author is in the wrong) because their response was a direct attack that likely exacerbated the situation, even if the friend's behavior was bad.
